metadata.title: A multiple center clinical evaluation of an ultra-fast single-tube assay for SARS-CoV-2 RNA

body_text.text: In December 2019, a pneumonia outbreak associated with a novel coronavirus occurred in Wuhan, Hubei Province, China [1]. This outbreak was named COVID-19 (coronavirus disease 2019) [2], and later this novel coronavirus was named as SARS-CoV-2 (severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus) [3].

At present, there is no effective treatment for COVID-19. The key to prevention and control lies in early diagnosis, early treatment and early isolation of patients. Therefore, rapid and accurate diagnosis of SARS-CoV-2 infection is very important to cut off the transmission chain. Virus isolation and culture is the gold standard of SARS-CoV-2 detection, but it is time-consuming and is limited to experimental conditions. Nucleic acid test is not only a vital tool for the diagnosis and differential diagnosis of SARS-CoV-2, but also a basis for judging the curative effect. Fluorescence quantitative RT-PCR (qRT-PCR) is the most widely used detection method of SARS-CoV-2 RNA. However, faster and simpler molecular detection assays are highly needed in resources-limited areas where the professional personnel and PCR cyclers are lacking. For example, in the community fever clinics, a large number of patients with fever need to be identified or rule out in a timely manner to prevent the potential cross-infection in the crowded clinics.

Compared with qRT-PCR, recombinase-aided amplification (RAA)-based assay is faster and simpler and the result can be obtained under a constant temperature with portable instruments within 30 min. Briefly, the principle of RAA is to use a recombinase binding tightly to the primer to form a complex of the enzyme and the primer. When the primer searches for a sequence completely complementary to the template DNA, strand replacement occurs between the primers and the template with the single-stranded DNA binding (SSB). In the presence of DNA polymerase, the new DNA fragment could be amplified rapidly in vitro. A specific fluorescent probe is added to the amplification system to realize RAA real-time monitoring. RAA has been successfully applied in the detection of adenovirus [4], pertussis [5], respiratory syncytial virus [6], coxsackievirus, enterovirus [7, 8] and Hepatitis B virus [9] in our previous reports.

Recently, we developed a single-tube reverse transcription recombinase-aided amplification (RT-RAA) assay for SARS-CoV-2. This RT-RAA kit was first launched on Jan. 29, 2020, and passed the external quality assessment of National Institute for Viral Disease Control and Prevention (IVDC), Chinese Center for disease control and prevention (CCDC) and Beijing CDC. In the present study, we report a multicenter clinical evaluation of this RT-RAA kit using a large number of clinical samples involved in five institutions in four regions, China.

The specificity evaluation panel was provided by National Institute for Viral Disease Control and Prevention (IVDC), Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CCDC). This panel consisted of inactivated culture of SARS-CoV-2, human coronavirus (CoV-229E, OC43, HKU1, NL63), human rhinovirus (HRV), Boca virus (HBoV), parainfluenza virus (PIV), respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), human metapneumovirus (HMPV), Influenza A virus, and chlamydia pneumonia (CP), streptococcus pneumoniae (SP) and Klebsiella pneumoniae (KPN). We obtained clinical samples from consecutive patients in five institutions from four regions in China (Hubei, Jiangsu, Zhejiang, Shanxi Province) for multicenter clinical evaluation. These samples were divided into four groups (A-D). Group A: Jiangsu CDC, Group B: Zhejiang CDC, Group C: Datong CDC, Shanxi Province, and the Fifth People's Hospital of Datong City, Shanxi Province, Group D: Hubei CDC. The specimens that can be processed within 24 hours were stored at 4°C, and those that cannot were stored at -70°C or below. All aspects of the study were performed in accordance with national ethics regulations and approved by the Institutional Review Boards of local CDCs and hospital mentioned above.

We downloaded the whole SARS-CoV-2genome sequences available from the Global Initiative on Sharing All Influenza Data (GISAID). We then selected the conserved region of ORF1ab gene of SARS-CoV-2 as the target. The corresponding primers and probes were designed using Oligo7 according to the principles required by RAA. A total of 46 pairs of primers and 2 probes candidates were synthesized by Sangon Biotech (Shanghai, China). A preliminary evaluation of the RT-RAA specificity was conducted in Silicon. We used the recombinant plasmid containing the target gene to screen the best set of primers and probes, the recombinant plasmid was diluted to 105, 104, 103, 102, 101, 2 and 1 copies/test, and non-ribozyme water was used as a negative control. We then used the specificity evaluation panel to further explore the specificity of RT-RAA kit for SARS-CoV-2, and finally two primers and one probe with the highest amplification efficiency were chosen.
body_text.section: Primer and probe design and analytical sensitivity and specificity of RT-RAA kit ::: Materials and methods

body_text.text: According to the instructions recommended by the manufacturer, the total RNA was extracted from 200 μL of sample preservation solution using Tian Long automatic extraction kit (Tian Long, Soochow, China). The nucleic acid was eluted in 50 μL of nuclease free water and stored at -80 °C until use.
body_text.section: Nucleic acid extraction ::: Materials and methods

body_text.text: We freeze-dried the selected primers and probe to the reaction unit tube, and made a single-tube SARS-CoV-2 nucleic acid isothermal amplification rapid detection kit (RT-RAA kit). A reaction system of 50 μL was set up. The system included one reaction unit tube containing lyophilized primer/probes and enzymes, 42.5 μL of reaction buffer, 2.5 μL of 280 mM magnesium acetate, 5 μL of extracted nucleic acid or 5 μL negative/positive control. A 42.5 μL buffer was added to each reaction unit tube with a pipette, and 2.5 μL magnesium acetate solution was added to the inside of the reaction tube cover. After that, the sample or negative and positive control was added. After capping the tube, the reaction tube was symmetrically placed in RAA-B6108 for mix and centrifugation for 7 minutes, the reaction tube was then removed and transferred to the nucleic acid amplification fluorescence detector RAA-F1620. The reaction temperature was set at 39°C for 10 minutes, and the time of each sample to reach the threshold could be measured in real time by the fluorescence signal detector.
body_text.section: Protocol of RT-RAA kit for SARS-CoV-2 ::: Materials and methods

body_text.text: The Technical Guide for Laboratory testing of COVID-19 (third Edition) recommended that the confirmed case of COVID-19 infection should be identified by qRT-PCR kits. So far, about 19qRT-PCR kits were officially approved by National Medical Products Administration (NMPA) and used in the detection of COVID-19 nationwide.
body_text.section: Reference qRT-PCR kits for SARS-CoV-2 detection ::: Materials and methods

body_text.text:
The reference qRT-PCR kits in this study were 2019-nCoV Detection Kit (BioGerm, Shanghai, China) for groups A and B, 2019-nCoV Detection Kit (Sansure, Hunan, China) for group C, 2019-nCoV Detection Kit (BGI, Shenzhen, China) for group D. All of them were approved by NMPA and certified by European Union CE certification. The parameters of the kits are shown in Table 1
. The qRT-PCR tests were performed in parallel with the RT-RAA kit at the cooperative sites where the samples were provided.
body_text.section: Reference qRT-PCR kits for SARS-CoV-2 detection ::: Materials and methods

body_text.text: All the experimental operation and biosafety protection in this study strictly abide by SARS-CoV-2 Laboratory Biosafety Guidelines (second Edition) [10] and Technical Guide for Laboratory testing of COVID-19 (fourth Edition) [11] issued by the General office of the State Health Commission.

IBM SPSS Statistics, version 21 (IBM Corporation, NY, USA) was used to perform all of the statistical analysis. The results of qRT-PCR assay and RT-RAA assay were analyzed using Kappa and McNemar's tests, and a value of P < 0.05 was considered statistically significant. Kappa stands for the measure of agreement between the two tests, and that> 0.9 is excellent. Linear regression analysis was used to analyze the relationship between the time threshold (min) detected by RT-RAA and the cycle threshold (Ct) of qRT-PCR method.
body_text.section: Statistical data analysis ::: Materials and methods

body_text.text:
A panel of diluted recombinant plasmids (105, 104, 103, 102, 101, 2, and 1 copies/test) were tested to ascertain the endpoint dilution. As shown in Fig. 1
, the sensitivity of RT-RAA kit was 2 copies per reaction. As shown in Fig. 2
, RT-RAA kit showed 100% specificity for SARS-CoV-2, no cross reaction with four common coronaviruses and other viral and bacterial pathogens was observed.
body_text.section: Sensitivity and specificity of the RT-RAA kit ::: Results

body_text.text: A total of 947 clinical specimens were obtained from patients with suspected pneumonia and SARS-CoV-2 infection from Jan 18, 2020 to Apr 1, 2020, of which 59.66% (565/947) were male. The age range was 7-93 years old, with an average age of 44 ± 17.1. The types of specimens included pharynx swab (834, 88.07%), sputum (82, 8.66%), nasopharyngeal swab (16, 1.69%), nasal swab (8, 0.84%), bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (4, 0.42%), stool (2, 0.21%), whole blood (1, 0.11%). The Ct values of qRT-PCR positive samples ranged from 8.59 to 39.07.

body_text.section: Comparison of RT-RAA and qRT-PCR ::: Results

body_text.text:
We showed the time distribution of partial RT-RAA positive samples (90 samples from group A, B and C, Fig. 3
) to explore the quantitative possibility of RT-RAA. The correlation between the time threshold (TT) (min) detected by RT-RAA and the cycle threshold (Ct) values of qRT-PCR method was weak with a coefficient R squared value of 0.303. The regression equation was Y = 0.08821*X - 2.005 (gradient: 0.08821, 95% CI: 0.06465 to 0.1634; intercept: -2.005, 95% CI: -2.841 to - 1.170, P <0.0001)
body_text.section: The time distribution of RT-RAA positive samples ::: Results

body_text.text: As shown in Fig 3, the time of most samples to reach the threshold was within 3 minutes, plus the pre-reaction of 7 minutes, thus 10 minutes warranted the positivity of most samples. As most of the samples with low viral load (Ct ≥ 35) had higher TT values, we prolonged and set up the detection time to 8 minutes to ascertain no occurrence of false-negatives, making the duration of total process within 15 minutes.
body_text.section: The time distribution of RT-RAA positive samples ::: Results

body_text.text: The manifestations of SARS-CoV-2 infection are highly non-specific, including respiratory symptoms, fever, cough, dyspnea and viral pneumonia [12]. A large number of qRT-PCR methods have been developed for specifically detecting SARS-CoV-2 [[13], [14], [15]], but they are not well suitable in the community. Point-of-care testing (POCT) is undoubtedly the most powerful detection in this regard, but the main obstacle of POCT is the relatively low throughput hence not ideal for rapid screening [16]. Isothermal nucleic acid amplifications, such as NASBA, LAMP [17, 18] and CRISPR's Sherlock technology [19, 20], are good alternatives to qRT-PCR, these methods showed comparable sensitivity and specificity to qRT-PCR in the detection of SARS-CoV-2 and relatively easier operation and shorter turn-around time, however, these reports only included limited clinical samples and data, the feasibility of these methods need to be further verified. In this study, we conduct a multicenter clinical evaluation of RT-RAA kit for SARS-CoV-2 using about 1000 samples. We also include respiratory tract samples (throat swabs, sputum, nasopharyngeal swabs, nasal swabs, bronchoalveolar lavage fluid) and non-respiratory samples (stool and whole blood), which makes our results more reliable and adaptable.

The most attractive feature of RAA kit is the ultra-fast speed of detection, making this kit ideal for rapid preliminary screening in clinical settings, particularly for applications in resource-poor settings. The detection results could be achieved in 8-15 minutes after addition of extracted nucleic acid. Actually, the time for vast majority of positive samples (corresponding Ct values ranged from 17.00-37.00) was within 10 minutes. As RT-RAA is able to test 16 sample per run, in practice, one person is able to finish 16 samples in 40 minutes by working with automatic DNA extraction. In addition, the RAA device is a portable equipment and easy to use. Moreover, the RT-RAA kits containing the lyophilized reaction pellets are very convenient for transport because lyophilized reagents are stable at room temperature. Like qRT-PCR kits, the single-tube design of RT-RAA also reduces the possibility of cross-contamination while has lower cost than that of qRT-PCR kits.

The proposed RT-RAA kit had a sensitivity of 2 copies per reaction using DNA template, which might not reflect the true sensitivity using RNA template. A total of 21 inconsistent samples either had high Ct values (positive only by qRT-PCR) or higher TT value (positive only by RT-RAA), highlighting the importance of cautious consideration of these positives. This discrepancy between two methods was not dissolved by repetitive experiments because of the heavy work burden during the outbreak in the institutions. The failure (potential false negative and false positive) of RT-RAA kit might be due to either the viral load is lower than the detection limit or operation errors or the difference in the sensitivity and specificity of different qRT-PCR kits used. Despite this inconsistence, compared with the commercial qRT-PCR kits, the total coincidence rate was 97.78% (926/947, 95% CI: 96.80 to 98.70), the Kappa value was 0.952 (P < 0.05), indicating the overall clinical performance of RT-RAA kit is comparable to those approved qRT-PCR kits.

Nevertheless, this study has a few limitations. The internal control is not included in the kit, not monitoring the occurrence of false-negatives. Additionally, only single gene (ORF1ab) is targeted thus the specificity or sensitivity might be compromised. The nucleic acid extraction step is not yet integrated in the RAA device thus hinders its portability of field detection. Further improvements to this RT-RAA kit are under way in this regard.

In conclusion, our results strongly demonstrate RT-RAA kit for SARS-CoV-2 shows comparable sensitivity and specificity to the commercial qRT-PCR kits, and exhibits distinctive advantages of simplicity and rapidity over qRT-PCR kits in terms of operation and turn-around time. This RT-RAA kit is therefore a promising tool to be potentially used in the resource-limited scenes or remote areas such as community fever clinics and mobile laboratories.
All authors disclose no conflicts of interest.

This work was supported by grants from the China Mega-Projects for Infectious Disease (2018ZX10711001, 2017ZX10104001 and 2018ZX10713-002), IVDC (2019HYDQNJJ03) and COVID-19 Prevention Research Program of Datong (2020-1).

XJM, WBX, YZJ designed the study; JW, KC, XZH, JL, JQX, FQ, WWL, LBC, YYG, TW, YJZ, HY, YC, JZY, XJM, HS performed the experiments; JW, XXS, JRW, RQZ, XNL, YG, PHN, WJT, GZW, analyzed and interpreted the data; XJM, JW, JRW wrote the paper. All authors provided a critical review and approved the final manuscript.
